slides.title: üìú La Storia di Jupyter
paragraphs: 2001: IPython (Fernando P√©rez) - Enhanced Python shell interattivo
2011: IPython Notebook - Web-based notebook (precursore di Jupyter)
2014: Project Jupyter - Spin-off da IPython, linguaggi multipli
Nome: Ju(lia) + Pyt(hon) + R = Jupyter (3 linguaggi core)
Oggi: Standard de-facto per Data Science, Machine Learning, ricerca scientifica
Usato da: Netflix, NASA, Bloomberg, Google, CERN, universit√† worldwide
slides.ironicClosing: Da shell Python a piattaforma globale. IPython: 'hold my beer, I'll change science'.

slides.title: üöÄ Jupyter 2025: Versioni Correnti
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ IDE-like interface con tab, split view, file browser
‚Ä¢ Perfetto per beginners o uso semplice
Raccomandazione: JupyterLab 4 per uso serio, Notebook 7 per semplicit√†
slides.ironicClosing: JupyterLab vs Notebook: IDE vs editor di testo. Entrambi validi, scegli il tuo fighter.

slides.title: Perch√© Jupyter?
paragraphs: Literate Programming: Codice + documentazione + visualizzazioni in un documento
Interattivit√†: Esegui codice cella per cella, vedi risultati immediatamente
Esplorazione dati: Prova codice, sperimenta, itera velocemente
Multi-linguaggio: Python, R, Julia, JavaScript, SQL, +40 kernel
Condivisione: .ipynb format, nbviewer, GitHub rendering, export PDF/HTML
‚Ä¢ Data Science, Machine Learning, Data Analysis
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: PowerPoint che esegue codice. O Word con superpowers. Scegli la metafora.

slides.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Errori Comuni Principianti
paragraphs: Problema: Variabile non definita, imports mancanti
Fix: Restart & Run All per verificare
Codice scritto ma non eseguito ‚Üí variabili non esistono
Fix: Shift+Enter per eseguire ogni cella
Cella in esecuzione infinita (loop, operazione lenta)
Print di array giganti, loop che stampa migliaia di righe
Fix: Clear output, limita print, usa head()/tail()
Jupyter autosave, ma meglio salvare manualmente
Fix: Clear output prima di commit, o usa nbstripout
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: 'cell [*]' significa 'vai a prendere un caff√®'. O 'hai un infinite loop'.

code.snippet:
%matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Line plot
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(x, y, label='sin(x)', linewidth=2)
plt.plot(x, np.cos(x), label='cos(x)', linewidth=2, linestyle='--')
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('y')
plt.title('Trigonometric Functions')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
plt.show()

# Scatter plot
x = np.random.randn(100)
y = np.random.randn(100)
colors = np.random.rand(100)

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
plt.scatter(x, y, c=colors, s=50, alpha=0.6, cmap='viridis')
plt.colorbar()
plt.xlabel('X')
plt.ylabel('Y')
plt.title('Scatter Plot')
plt.show()

# Subplots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))
axes[0, 0].plot(x, y)
axes[0, 1].hist(x, bins=20)
axes[1, 0].scatter(x, y)
axes[1, 1].bar([1, 2, 3], [10, 20, 15])
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

code.snippet:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Set style
sns.set_style('whitegrid')
sns.set_palette('husl')

# Sample data
tips = sns.load_dataset('tips')

# Distribution plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.histplot(tips['total_bill'], kde=True, bins=30)
plt.title('Distribution of Total Bill')
plt.show()

# Box plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.boxplot(x='day', y='total_bill', hue='sex', data=tips)
plt.title('Total Bill by Day and Sex')
plt.show()

# Violin plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.violinplot(x='day', y='total_bill', data=tips)
plt.show()

# Correlation heatmap
iris = sns.load_dataset('iris')
corr = iris.corr(numeric_only=True)
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
sns.heatmap(corr, annot=True, cmap='coolwarm', center=0)
plt.title('Correlation Matrix')
plt.show()

# Pairplot
sns.pairplot(iris, hue='species')
plt.show()

import plotly.express as px

    df,

    size='petal_length',

)

    x='sepal_length',
    y='sepal_width',

import altair as alt

# Load data

    x='Horsepower',

).interactive()

chart

# Bar chart con sorting

    x=alt.X('Origin:N', sort='-y'),

bars

).add_selection(selection)

slides.title: üíª ipywidgets: Interactive UI

code.snippet:
import ipywidgets as widgets
from IPython.display import display
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Slider
slider = widgets.IntSlider(
    value=50,
    min=0,
    max=100,
    step=1,
    description='Value:'
)
display(slider)

# Button
button = widgets.Button(description='Click me!')
def on_button_click(b):
    print('Button clicked!')
button.on_click(on_button_click)
display(button)

# Dropdown
dropdown = widgets.Dropdown(
    options=['Option 1', 'Option 2', 'Option 3'],
    value='Option 1',
    description='Select:'
)
display(dropdown)

# Interactive plot
@widgets.interact(freq=(1, 10, 0.5), amplitude=(0.1, 2, 0.1))
def plot_sine(freq=1, amplitude=1):
    x = np.linspace(0, 4*np.pi, 100)
    y = amplitude * np.sin(freq * x)
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 4))
    plt.plot(x, y)
    plt.ylim(-2, 2)
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.show()

# Multiple widgets
slider1 = widgets.FloatSlider(value=1, min=0, max=5, description='A:')
slider2 = widgets.FloatSlider(value=1, min=0, max=5, description='B:')
output = widgets.interactive_output(
    lambda a, b: print(f'Sum: {a+b}'),
    {'a': slider1, 'b': slider2}
)
display(widgets.VBox([slider1, slider2, output]))

slides.explanation: ipywidgets per interactivity. Sliders, buttons, dropdowns. @interact decorator.
